And then on the other side of GE Money, as we have said, there are going to be some assets dispositions that we'll do and we did anticipate that some of those would fund some of the provisions and some of the comparisons to securitizations, like the Corporate Card did in the first quarter. I don't have a specific number on that though.
That's fine. But basically you're suggesting aim toward the low end of 2.20 to 2.30. But if you sell the PLCC business, that's -- would you say $0.04 of gain in that?

I said the PLCC, what we would – David (sic), if you looked at our guidance and you said that PLCC was going to be sold, that has about $0.04 of earnings in our year and the 2.20 to 2.30, we would say you should probably take that out.
So there is no gain from the PLCC in the numbers?
That's correct, that's correct. I'm sorry I didn't say that clearer.

No. Okay, now I get it. Just a couple of more quick ones; so just going back to the point about the misses in Healthcare, and obviously we all know that the economy is tough. Jeff, are you contemplating management changes, not necessarily senior management changes, but maybe other operational changes or structural, some kind of structural shakeup to perhaps refocus some of these businesses in the next couple of years? How should we think about what's going on behind the scenes now at GE?

I think we like the Healthcare business from the outset. We like where it's positioned. We like the demographic positioning of the company. Over a long period of time, it has been a good performer. John, again, I think there are certain things that are market based. There are certain things that are our bad execution. I'm not at all happy about having a plant shut down for 20 months by the FDA. I think that's all on us. And so we have already made some management changes associated with that. And look, if people don't perform here, we still work very hard; and if you just look at the set of officers in the Annual Report every year, there is a different group every year, and people have to perform to stay here. So look, I mean I just think we believe in the Healthcare franchise and we've got to get this plant back up and going. I think once we do that, this is a business that's going to perform in 2008.

Yes, and just lastly, Keith, how are you guys thinking about the AAA? Maybe you could just size – are there risks to the AAA given the Financial Services environment or do you guys feel still pretty good that you are in pretty good shape to preserve it?

We feel great about it. We have an incredible discipline from the Board of Directors to the leadership team of this company, to the actions we take in GE Capital and the Capital Board to run the company as a AAA. We have an incredible risk management process. We have a great liquidity profile. We are in contact with the rating agencies every week on all sorts of things around the world, and both the rating agencies understand where we are and they are both supportive of us keeping the AAA today and in the future.

We believe in funding ourselves for safety and security first. That's why we did our debt plan to get ahead of the year. We had a year planned to doing about $80 billion of long term debt. We did 35 in the first quarter. Even though the markets were tough, we went out and did the debt to get it in place in advance of some of the transactions we think we're going to do. We have been very disciplined about our commercial paper, keeping it right around a $100 billion balance. We ended the quarter I think at $102 billion. We could have a much higher balance of commercial paper, but we have chosen to keep that at a certain level so that it's completely aligned with all our liquidity backup plans. We have a cash balance and a liquidity plan that we keep in place for any type of temporary disruption. And we feel great about the business, the underlying business model that we have and the rating agencies agree with us, John.
Okay, thanks very much.
Yes.
Our next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan with Bear Stearns. Go ahead.
Hi guys. Good morning.
Good morning, Ann.

It's a tough day to be a Bear Stearns employee considering the impact it has had on you guys. Quick follow-up questions, just curious; I think you said that your outlook for tax rate now is 16% versus your initial guidance of 18%. Is that correct or did I pick it up wrong?
No, that's correct.
Okay. And you didn't call that out in your revised '08 framework, but that would have had a positive impact?
We revised it from 18 to 16, but if you look at the revised EPS guidance, the reduction in the Financial Services earnings includes the impact of the lower tax rate.
Okay. So that's where...
So, we have taken into account in the Financial Services EPS range.

Okay. And then I think most of my questions have been answered, but what are you seeing? I know you said that you aren't seeing a significant slowdown in your long-cycle businesses in Western Europe and places outside of the US, but what are things like GE Money seeing in Europe, particularly in Eastern Europe? Is there any knock-on effect or are you anticipating any knock-on effect in other regions of the world?

Actually in GE Money, I would say the one place we have seen an increase in delinquencies is in the secured book in the UK, which is our iGroup mortgage book. It's up around 14% delinquency. We have seen those rates over the last three years go as high as 17 – 18%. That is the one place globally we have seen an increase in delinquency. We do not have any losses rolling through in that book. We have very low loan to value exposure. We have mortgage insurance that we use anytime it gets above 80%. We underwrite all those loans to the highest possible rate that could impact the consumer based on what they've – how they've borrowed. And we have got a very good business team there. And everything obviously after all the lessons we learned in WMC, we went over and made sure we applied all those in our global mortgage business. So, I think we're in pretty good shape there. And the rest of the delinquencies outside of the US and outside of that UK secured book are actually down in GE Money globally. So, we feel pretty good about the global balance sheet asset quality at GE Money outside the pressure we're seeing in the Americas, Ann.

Okay, and finally just one quick follow-up. Commercial aftermarket and aerospace I think you said was down 3% in the quarter. Is there any risk to that business as we look at higher fuel prices and all the complexities that are going on in the aerospace industry right now? I know original equipment demand remains strong around the world. But what about aftermarket, particularly in the US as we begin to see activities slow maybe in this region?

I think overall, first of all you have seen a couple of airlines go bankrupt in the last couple of weeks. Number one, we don't have any significant exposure to them. Everything we have is secured by relatively new aircraft. I think the total was around $100 million for the couple that went bankrupt. And we have very good position in great planes, Ann. The revenue passenger mile growth is what really drives our aftermarket performance year-end, and you know the revenue pass-through miles were up 4.5% in the quarter. So the airlines are flying, and as long as they are flying, we're going to be doing more maintenance, and I think the things that are getting pressured will be the older, less fuel efficient engines and that's not the bigger proportion of our mix. We have got a lot of the new aircraft out there.

So I think number one, we can't get enough planes today based on the global demand. You don't really feel that when you're sitting here reading about ATA or Aloha going bankrupt. But it's true; Henry Hubschman and the team could really use more aircraft. Our order book is placed through 2009 and I think almost all of 2010 is now placed for new aircraft we're getting out of Airbus and Boeing, so the global demand is incredibly strong. The aircraft values are very good. And I think we're going to have to deal with the airlines being under financial pressure because of fuel and we have seen that cycle obviously a lot of times in the last ten years. So we feel pretty good about it, but it's some obviously we have to watch.
Okay, thank you. I will take my other questions offline.
Thanks, Ann.
Melanie, we'd like to take the last question, please.
Yes, sir. Our final question comes from the line of Nigel Coe with Deutsche Bank. Go ahead.

Thanks; 45 minutes of Q&A; I admire your stamina for tough questions. So you've done 11% in the first half trading. It looks like the market is parked at 2.20 already for the full year. I guess the downside here would be if anything happens in Infrastructure and I tend to agree that 2008 is in the bag. But orders were a little bit lighter this quarter, and I understand it is lumpy and that could be the reason. But is there any sign that the tighter credit conditions or slowing global growth is causing orders to get pushed back or canceled and therefore we might see orders weaken from here?

Actually, we haven't seen that. I would say just a couple of the numbers on the orders, just so I can give them to you and then I want to tell you about what I think the next phase is coming. If you look at the dollars of orders in Infrastructure, up 11%, not the 30% that we have been averaging, but if you look at, we did 10.5 billion in the first quarter last year of major equipment orders, 12.8 billion in the second quarter, 11.7 in the third quarter, 13.8 in the third (sic) [fourth] quarter; all 1.2 to 1.4 times the revenue we had in the quarter, building an incredible backlog. Total orders last year were $50 billion, up 29%; and the absolute level of orders that we have this year at 11.7 in the first quarter against some tough comparisons, up 11.

And I think the thing that is really positive is we're just now starting to see a little bit of gas turbine ordering in the US. In the first quarter, I think we had four orders out of the 39 that were for the US and if you look at the energy dynamics in this country, and you look at supply/demand, and you look at the need for more capacity, and you look at the environmental regulations, and you look how difficult it is to site a nuclear plant, and you are selling every wind turbine you possibly can, gas turbines are going to be sold in this country. And the price is greater than inflation in that business, and so I feel like this is really in good shape. I can't say never say never, but this is the most sustainable, long cycle, positive revenue generating thing that I have seen in GE in my career.
Okay. So just some of the indicators for orders, tender activity, proposals, that's all consistent with what you expect at this stage?

I think the Energy business, you're going to continue to see incredible. I think Oil & Gas is going to continue to be very strong. I think you're going to see lumpiness in Aviation because Airbus and Boeing are basically full through 2011 – 2012. So I think that's the one place, Nigel, where you say you got to expect that to level off, just based on how full people are based on things like the push-outs of the 787, the push-out of the Airbus deliveries. I think that's the one place that you say we have got to see a leveling off in Aviation. But again it's leveling off at a very, very good number for us.

Fair enough; and sometimes we even hear. So two quick questions; price inflation spread is still positive, but it is much narrower in the second half of the year. Fuel prices are on a tear. What are you baking into the second half of the year for that spread?

We're going to still have a positive value gap in the Infrastructure business. I think we have pressure in Healthcare where the price erosion does not offset inflation, and we got to recover some of that price/value gap in the Industrial segment. So Infrastructure is the power, and overall for the whole company, our price inflation gap was positive. And for the whole year, we expect it to be positive, driven by Infrastructure.

Okay, and then just finally in your runoff insurance business, you do have some unrealized losses on the securities in that business. I understand that these are held to maturity securities, so they're not mark-to-market. What would have to happen for you to actually realize that loss?

Basically in the Investment Securities portfolio, you have to determine that the securities are other than temporarily impaired. We have a process where every quarter, you look at what is the security. We do a discounted cash flow underwriting of the company. We look at whether it's a credit issue or a market issue, and we look at how long it has been underwater. And we have to periodically take those impairments that are other than temporary and put them into the P&L based on that discipline process, and we have been doing that for years obviously since we have had that portfolio forever here.
Okay. Thanks a lot.
Yes.
I would like to thank everybody. Joanna and I will be available all day. And transcripts and other information will be available on our website. So thank you very much.
This concludes your conference call. Thank you for your participation today. You may now disconnect. Have a wonderful day.
